The proposed Roads for Rural Development Project (Project) will 
address  accessibility  to  poor,  rural  districts  in  the  Lao  PDR 
through improvement of the transport network. The Project will (i) 
rehabilitate about 292 kilometers (km) of selected roads to remote 
rural  regions,  (ii)  provide  supplementary 
for  road

safety, and (iv) provide a study of tariffs and policies for transport 
services to promote increased efficiency in road transportation.

The  areas  served  by  the  rural  roads  proposed  for  upgrading  are 
among  the  poorest  in  the  Lao  PDR  in  terms  of  access  to  health 
care,  education,  and  other  services.  Each  road  selected  will 
improve  access  to  one  of  the  priority  47  poorest  districts  in  the 
country.  Most  of  the  local  populations  in  the  project  area  have 
high levels of disease, malnutrition, and illiteracy. Few areas have 
access  to  safe  water,  sanitation,  and  electricity.  The  Project  will 
relieve the isolation of these areas by reducing cost and time for 
travel,  and  eliminating  the  disruption  of  traffic  during  the  wet 
season.  That  will  enable  continuous 
trade  and  economic 
exchange, and nondisrupted access to schools, medical facilities, 
and  other  social  and  civil  services.  The  Project  components  are 
consistent with  the  priorities  agreed  to  in  the  Government  of  Lao 
PDR’s  National  Poverty  Eradication  Program, 
the  Asian 
Development  Bank’s  (ADB)  Medium-Term  Transport  Strategy  for 
the  Lao  PDR,  and  the  draft  Northern  Region  Infrastructure 
Development  Strategy  currently  under  preparation  through  an 
ADB technical assistance (TA). 

The  overall  purpose  of  the  Project  is  to  provide  the  rural  poor 
better  access  to  markets,  employment,  and  social  facilities  and 
thus, to contribute to economic growth and poverty reduction.

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

2. 
The landlocked Lao PDR is poor, mountainous, and sparsely populated. Most of the poor 
live in rural areas with limited access. Road access is a key condition that underlies the potential 
for poverty reduction in the Lao PDR, both in terms of ability and cost effectiveness of targeting 
services  to  the  poor,  as  well  as  the  benefits  in  poverty  reduction  that  result  from  economic 
growth.  Improved  road  access  will  remove  cost  barriers  in  the  provision  of  social  services  and 
enhance the ability of the poor to benefit from overall economic growth. Thus, poverty reduction 
through  improved  accessibility  can  be  both  direct  and  indirect,  with  multisectoral  implications, 
especially in education and health. 

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analyses 

3.
The  Road  Network.  Transport  in  the  Lao  PDR  is  almost  exclusively  by  road.  Roads 
carry  about  70%  of  freight  and  90%  of  passenger  traffic,  and  are  a  key  element  of  the  basic 
infrastructure  supporting  national  and  international  trade.  Density  of  the  road  network  is  low: 
about 0.14 km/sq km. Road contact between Vientiane and the provincial capitals is improving, 
but 4 of the 18 provincial capitals remain without all-weather links. Only 14% of the road network 
is paved, including about half of the national road system. The other roads have gravel or earth 
surfaces. Much of the local network is impassable during the wet season. Traffic is generally low 
on national and provincial roads throughout the Lao PDR. The road network is a major asset for 
any  country.  Ensuring  that  the  value  of  roads  is  not  lost  requires  timely  and  effective 
maintenance,  based  on  a  strategy  that  targets  the  road  network  as  a  whole.  That  strategy  is 
based  on  information  on  the  condition  of  individual  roads.  To  meet  this  objective,  the 
Government  established  a  Road  Maintenance  Fund  (RMF)  in  2001  to  provide  sustainable, 
domestic funding for maintenance of the national road network, and eventually, all Lao roads. An 
analysis of the road subsector is given in Appendix 1. 

Transport  Services.  Transport  services,  for  both  freight  and  passengers,  are  available 
4.
over the entire road network, although quality and frequency reflect the quality and remoteness 
of access roads. The extent to which benefits of road improvement are transferred to end-users 
is determined by the availability and competition of transport services. Private operators provide 
most  transport  services,  which  are  mainly  regulated  by  the  provincial  transport  associations. 
These  associations  act  as  regulatory  bodies  for  outreach,  routing,  and  frequency  of  services. 
The  transport  associations,  although  private  in  principle,  report  to  provincial  departments  of 
communication, transport, post, and construction (DCTPC). The provincial governor is the tariff 
regulator and approves tariffs along the routes yearly, based on diesel costs, road quality, and 
other  costs  of  vehicle  maintenance.  Findings  suggest  that  the  initial  benefits  to  end  users  of 
improved road access is significant where accessibility has been severely restricted; benefits of 
transport availability increase with all-weather accessibility. But the transfer of vehicle costs and 
time  savings  from  providers  to  end  consumers  is  less  obvious  for  improved  road  sections  that 
were  previously  accessible  but  are now  improved.  The  extent  to  which  regulations  in  transport 
services reduce net benefits to end users of services in the Lao PDR is not clear.

5.
Road  Safety.  Road  accident  fatalities  in  the  Lao  PDR  rose  245%  from  1991  to  1999. 
Road  accidents  increased  176%.  Road  fatalities  are  the  highest  among  Southeast  Asian 
countries: almost 20 persons per 10,000 vehicles. The potential for even greater accident rates 
is  high,  considering  the  increase  in  vehicles,  the  growing  population,  and  increased  vehicle 
speeds  from  improvements  to  the  road  network.  A  national  road  safety  strategy  has  been 
prepared, but implementation has not started.    

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

6.
The Government’s Strategy. The Government has given high priority to improvement of 
the road transport system, mainly to facilitate (i) movement of agricultural products from surplus 
to deficit areas, (ii) flow of consumer goods and agricultural inputs to rural areas, (iii) marketing 
and export of cash crops and other produce, and (iv) participation in regional and international 
trade. The targets for physical infrastructure development include (i) completing the national road 
network,  (ii)  improving  the  provincial  road  network,  (iii)  upgrading  transit  routes,  and  (iv) 
establishing a sustainable maintenance system to preserve the country’s transport infrastructure. 
All-weather  access  is  being  provided  to  16  of  the  Government's  list  of  the  46  poorest  districts 
under  current  or  committed  ADB  projects,  including  Loan  1533-LAO(SF):  Xieng  Khuang  Road 
Improvement,  and  Loan  1795-LAO(SF):  Rural  Access  Roads.  MCTPC  is  addressing  the 
improvement of access to the districts that lack year-round road access, and provision of road 
access to areas that that lack it entirely, under an ongoing plan as part of the National Poverty 
Eradication Program (NPEP). 

ADB Strategy. The ADB strategy for the road subsector in the Lao PDR1 proposes that 
7.
ADB’s  main  development  focus  for  the  medium  term  be  to  induce  rural  development  through 
increasing  access  of  rural  areas  to  markets.  Priority  is  to  be  on  providing  access  to  provinces 
with poor connections to the main network, and to completing “missing links” in the road network. 
These  priorities  are  consistent  with  those  proposed  in  the  Government  of  Lao  PDR’s  NPEP, 
prepared  in  2003,  and  the  draft  Northern  Region  Infrastructure  Development  Strategy  being 
prepared under an ADB technical assistance (TA).2 The Lao PDR faces a number of transport-
related challenges that can be broadly subdivided into four major groups: (i) the need to develop 
reliable  road  access  throughout  the  country,  to  promote  economic  development,  poverty 
reduction,  and  cohesion;  (ii)  the  need  to  improve  road  management,  especially  road 
maintenance and its funding, to secure existing and future road assets; (iii) the need to reduce 
the  high  and  growing  rates  of  road  accidents,  with  their  rapidly  growing  economic  and  social 
costs; and (iv) the provision of efficient transport services. 

8.
External  Assistance  to  the  Road  Subsector.  ADB  has  been  a  major  contributor  to 
development  of  the  road  sector  in  the  Lao  PDR  by  providing  11  loans  amounting  to  $319.0 
million and 30 TA grants totaling $13.8 million. ADB’s assistance to the sector represents 36% of 
the $727.0 million of assistance by multilateral and bilateral organizations. Most of the external 
financing  has  been  directed  to  national  and  provincial  roads,  as  well  as  to  bridges  over  the 
Mekong River (Appendix 2).

III. 

THE PROPOSED PROJECT 

A. 

Objective 

The  goal  of  the  Project  is  to  induce  economic  development  and  social  integration,  and 
11. 
thereby to reduce poverty, through the connection of all district and provincial centers in the Lao 
PDR, both to each other and to the Lao national economy. This network of all-weather roads is 
to be well maintained and is to support efficient transport services. The purpose of the Project is 
to increase access to adequate, reliable, affordable, and safe all-year road transport in remote 
rural  regions.  This  goal  is  consistent  with  priorities  set  out  in  NPEP,  ADB’s  Medium-Term 
Transport  Strategy  for  the  Lao  PDR  (footnote  1),  and  the  draft  Northern  Region  Infrastructure 
Development Strategy, currently being prepared under an ADB TA (footnote 2). 

12. 
Economic  growth  has  had  significant  impact  on  poverty  reduction  in  the  Lao  PDR.  But 
most  of  the  poor  live  in  rural  areas,5  so  poverty  reduction  requires  that  investments  be 
geographically  focused  to  poor  areas  with  the  potential  for  trade  and  economic  growth.  A  key 
determinant  of  rural  poverty  in  the  Lao  PDR  is  rice  insufficiency.6  A  lack  of  sufficient  rice  is 
largely caused by reliance on subsistence agriculture, external shocks, and a lack of access to 
markets. 

The development objective of the Project is to reduce poverty and facilitate economic and

rehabilitate  selected  roads  to  remote  rural  regions,  (ii)  provide  funding  for  supplementary  road

B. 

Components and Outputs 

1. 

Rural Development Roads 

14. 
The  rural  development  roads  component  of  the  Project  will  upgrade  provincial  and 
national roads to provide access to rural areas that now have inadequate access to markets. All 
proposed  roads  either  pass  through  or  connect  to  one  of  the  47  poorest  districts  identified  in 
NPEP  where  connections  to  these  districts  were  given  priority.  Roads  for  the  Project  were 
identified  through  an  initial  screening  based  on  provincial  priorities,  poverty  indicators,  and 
linkages  to  the  national  road  network.  This  initial  screening  was  further  refined  using  a  multi-
criteria analysis that took into account traffic; impact on poverty; agricultural potential; linkages to 
the national network, external trade, and other development projects; social and environmental 
sensitivity;  and  gender  issues.  The  final  selection  was  confirmed  during  project  preparation. 
Improvement of the five roads selected for this component will be implemented in three phases. 
In the first phase, the Xaisetha-Sanxai road, in Attapeu Province, and the Pakxane-Thasi road, 
in Borikhamxay Province, will be upgraded. Detailed design and implementation documentation 
will be prepared for the Pakton-Ban Vang road in Vientiane Province, and the Hongsa-Thaxoan 
road  in  Sayabury  Province.  Implementation  documentation  will  include resettlement  and  ethnic 
minorities plans, as appropriate, and bidding documents. In the second phase, the Pakton-Ban 
Vang and Hongsa-Thaxoan roads will be upgraded. Work during project preparation showed that 
upgrading  of  the  Sayabury-Hongsa  road  in  Sayabury  Province  was  viable,  but  at  the  time  of 
project  appraisal  insufficient  funds  were  available  to  be  applied  to  the  upgrading  of  the  entire 
road. Therefore, it is proposed that once civil works contracts for the above two second phase 
roads have been awarded, the remaining project funds be applied to the Sayabury-Hongsa road. 
An economically viable extent of work, based on available funds, will be determined. This will be 
the  basis  for  preparing  detailed  designs  and  implementation  documentation,  as  for  the  phase-
two  roads.  In  the  third  phase,  the  Sayabury-Hongsa  road  will  be  upgraded.  Appendix  4  gives 
detailed descriptions of the civil works for each road. The Xaisetha-Sanxai road will pass through 
an  area  contaminated  with  unexploded  ordinance  (UXO).  The  Project  includes  UXO  clearance 
along the road as part of the civil works.

1. 

Economic Benefits 

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

47. 
The Project will promote economic growth and social development in rural areas where 
access  is  severely  constrained  by  establishing  efficient  all-weather  road  access  to  the  Sanxai 
area  in  Attapeu  Province,  the  Thasi  area  in  Borikhamxay  Province,  the  Ban  Vang  area  in 
Vientiane Province, and the Hongsa-Thaxoang area in Sayabury Province. Project benefits will 
be directly related to traffic, including (i) savings in vehicle operating costs, (ii) savings in costs of 
freight and passenger time, and (iii) induced benefits from traffic generated by the reduction in 
transport  costs  and  improvement  of  accessibility.  Based  on  assessment  of  the  direct  benefits 
and costs, an estimate of the Project’s economic viability was prepared. It indicates the Project's 
economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  as  17.1%.  The  benefit  and  cost  analysis  also  showed 
that  the  Hongsa-Ngeun  road,  one  of  six  roads  examined  for  inclusion,  was  not  economically 
viable, so it was excluded. The Sayabury-Hongsa road is marginally economically viable, but the 
extent of rehabilitated is subject to budget availability and the economic viability of rehabilitating 
its various subsections. Indirect benefits from generated traffic include producer surplus benefits 
and additional income and employment in other sectors due to increased agricultural activity and 
income. These benefits were not included in the quantitative assessment of benefits. Therefore, 
the EIRR can be regarded as a conservative estimate of economic and development impacts. 

48.  Work has been undertaken to examine the distributional impacts of the project roads. Net 
economic benefits have been distributed among key stakeholders, including poor and non-poor 
end users. The poor are estimated to comprise 60% of the project beneficiaries, and the poverty 
impact  ratio  (PIR)  is  estimated  at  0.82.  This  shows  that  the  requirements  have  been  met  for 
classification as a core poverty intervention based on (i) most beneficiaries are below the poverty 
line and (ii) the poor will reap most of the benefits. The distribution analysis further shows that 
the  extent  of  transmission  of  savings  in  vehicle  operating  costs  to  end  users  impacts  the  PIR 
significantly. But risk analysis indicates more than an 80% chance that the project PIR will be at 
least  0.50.  Appendix  11  summarizes  economic  analyses  for  the  Project.  Supplementary 
Appendix D describes the analyses in more detail.  

2. 

Ethnic Minority and Other Vulnerable Groups  

The Project will increase the benefits accruing to vulnerable ethnic minority communities

The  Project  will  also provide  the  opportunity  for  the  two  vulnerable  communities  to  sustainably

B. 

Impacts 

1. 

Poverty Impact 

50. 
Poverty in the project areas ranges from more than 87% to about 7%. The project roads 
connect  rice-deficit  areas,  with  high  poverty  and  vulnerability,  with  rice-surplus  areas,  where 

 15

poverty  is  substantially  lower  and  welfare,  generally  higher.  Relationships  of  rice  deficits,  low 
accessibility,  and  poverty  are  visible  along  the  project  roads.  Differences  in  prices,  reflecting 
differences in market access, are significant among road segments. Prices of inputs and outputs, 
and  of  food,  are  expected  to  decrease.  This  will  encourage  agriculture  beyond  subsistence 
production,  and  improve  livelihoods  of  marginal  farmers  who  are  now  unable,  or  face 
disincentives, to invest to improve productivity. Food prices for the landless poor will decrease, 
and increased local production and inflow of food will reduce their vulnerability. This impact could 
be the single most important factor in reducing food poverty15 in access-deprived communities. 

51. 
Opportunities for nonfarm employment are expected to increase, both through improved 
mobility  of  local  people,  and  better  investment  opportunities  because  of  better  market  access. 
This will, in turn, reduce dependence on subsistence farming, and resulting vulnerability. Another 
key  impact  identified  is  through  better  access  to  medical  facilities  and  services.  The  access-
deprived communities now have no access to medical services for several months of the year. 
Furthermore,  improved  road  access  will  greatly  enhance  the  public  sector’s  ability  to  provide 
these  services  efficiently.  Appendix  12  summarizes  the  Project’s  poverty  reduction  and  social 
strategies.

52. 
The impact on poverty was quantified by examining the share of total net benefits to the 
poor (Appendix 11, Supplementary Appendix D). A distribution analysis suggests that economic 
benefits generated by the proposed project will be strongly pro-poor. Four subprojects have PIRs 
from  0.54  to  0.82,  implying  that  they  disproportionately  benefit  the  poor.  The  fifth  subproject 
(where  a  PIR  cannot  be  computed  for  technical  reasons)  generates  pro-poor  growth  in  the 
strictest sense, such as the redistribution of resources from rich to poor. Overall, the Project has 
a 0.82 PIR. The high PIR reflects a high incidence of poverty among direct beneficiaries and a 
substantial net transfer of resources from the overall economy to the project area. An important 
underlying assumption is that project benefits, mostly savings in vehicle operating costs and time 
savings for travelers, are substantially transferred to end users. Here it has been assumed that 
two thirds of savings in vehicle operating costs are transmitted into lower transport charges for 
end users. Sensitivity analysis shows that this proportion can be reduced to about 35%, before 
the PIR falls below 0.50.

2.

53. 
The  Project  has  been  classified  as  Category  B  (sensitive),  as  defined  in  the  ADB’s 
Environment  Policy.  Project  work  is  mostly  to  improve  existing  accesses,  but  short  lengths  of 
new road will be built to either bypass towns or to avoid steep gradients. No project roads pass 
through  “National  Biodiversity  Conservation  Areas,”  but  one  road  passes  through  an  area

sensitive.  The  Project  will  have  short-term  and  manageable  environmental  impacts,  mainly 
related  to  construction.  The  Project  also  includes  construction  of  facilities  for  forest  product

3. 

Resettlement  

55. 
The Project will cause significant involuntary resettlement, including relocation of houses 
and loss of agricultural and homestead land (para. 21). Land acquisition has been minimized by 
construction  of  a  bypass  in  Bolikham  on  the  Pakxane-Thasi  road,  and  by  minimizing  the 
construction  corridors.  Adverse  impacts  will  be  mitigated  through  resettlement  planning  and 
implementation in accordance with ADB’s Policy on Involuntary Resettlement and the Lao PDR 
Government’s  Decree  on  Resettlement  and  Compensation.  The  objective  is  to  improve  or  at 
least restore current living standards, income earning capacity, and production levels of affected 
people. Special assistance will be given to help the poorest and most vulnerable people improve 
their socioeconomic status. 

4. 

HIV/AIDS and Other Sexually Transmitted Diseases 

56. 
The  Project  will  increase  the  potential  for  the  spread  of  HIV/AIDs  and  other  STDs 
because  of  the  influx  of  construction  workers  and  increased  communication.  This  potential  will 
be  mitigated  or  minimized  through  a  program  to  increase  awareness  and  provide  preventive 
measures for the local communities, mobile populations, and construction workers. 

5. 

Trafficking of Women and Children  

57. 
Better  roads  facilitate  movement  away  from  communities  that  offer  few  employment  or 
livelihood options. Such migration can be positive, if the process is safe. But such migration can 
also cause exploitation by human traffickers. The construction phase will bring large numbers of 
temporary laborers and with them, increased demand for sex workers, introduction of new ideas, 
and  employment  opportunities.  Efforts  to  raise  awareness  of  the  dangers  of  trafficking,  and 
providing safe migration services, will help prevent negative effects from increased mobility from 
areas  with  improved  roads  and  from  the  influx  of  outside  laborers.  The  Projects  includes  no 
international border crossings.

6. 

Traffic Safety  

58. 
Road improvements will increase the potential for traffic accidents because of increased 
traffic volumes and higher speed. The roads are currently an integral part of village communities; 
children  play  in  the  road,  and  animals  and  pedestrians  amble  across  them.  The  potential  for 
increased  accidents  will  be  mitigated  by  erection  of  bamboo  fences  along  village  household 
properties,  introduction  of  traffic  safety  measures,  and  community  road  safety  and  awareness 
programs.

C. 

Risks 

59. 
The  main  risks  associated  with  the  Project  during  construction  are  (i)  delayed  or 
inadequate  execution  of  mitigating  measures,  especially  for  resettlement;  (ii)  delayed  or  poor 
performance  of  contractors  and  supervisors;  (iii)  delayed  funding  for  procurement  and  local 
counterparts;  and  (iv)  environmental  degradation  due  to  insufficient  cleanup  and  mitigation  by 
the  contractors.  After  construction,  the  main  risks  are  (i)  lower-than-expected  traffic,  (ii) 
inadequate  transfer  of  savings  in  vehicle  operation  costs  to  users  of  public  transport,  (iii) 
increased  traffic  accidents  and  fatalities,  and  (iv)  insufficient  funding  for  road  maintenance. 
Lesser risks are failure of transport provision and failure of agricultural development because of 
unrelated  constraints.  Neither  risk  is  considered  likely  to  materialize,  given  the  findings  of  the 
preparatory TA and previous project experience. Other concerns are the risks of increased illegal 
logging, increased illegal wildlife endangerment and/or gathering, illegal trafficking of women and 
children  across  borders,  and  increased  land  grabbing  due  to  insecure  land  tenure  by  persons 
with  land  near  the  rehabilitated  roads.  The  Project’s  interventions  and  mitigating  measures 
should adequately alleviate these concerns. Considering the Project’s high economic return, the 
benefits are expected to outweigh the costs.

THE ROAD SUBSECTOR 

A. 

Subsector Performance 

1. 

Transport Planning and Coordination 

1. 
The  Ministry  of  Communications,  Transport,  Post,  and  Construction  (MCTPC)  is 
responsible  for  the  development  of  national  and  provincial  roads,  civil  aviation,  urban 
development,  telecommunications,  river  wharves,  and  river  and  road  transport  in  the  Lao 
People’s  Democratic  Republic  (the  Lao  PDR).  Based  on  the  5-year  development  plan,  the 
provinces  prepare  and  submit  annual  implementation  plans  for  transport  projects  to  MCTPC, 
which then submits the plans to the Committee for Planning and Cooperation for approval. 

2. 
The  Department  of  Roads  (DOR)  in  MCTPC  is  responsible  for  the  administration, 
planning,  construction,  and  maintenance  of  national  roads.  DOR  monitors  maintenance 
programs  for  national  roads  and  assists  the  provinces  with  implementation  and  monitoring  of 
road  improvement  and  maintenance  programs  for  the  local  road  network.  The  actual 
responsibility for execution of all routine and periodic maintenance is delegated to the provincial 
Departments of Communication, Transport, Post and Construction (DCTPCs), which also cover 
district  and  community  roads,  and  access  roads.  DCTPCs  are  the  provincial  arms  of  MCTPC, 
and  are  responsible  both  to  Government  through  the  MCTPC  and  to  the  provincial 
administrations. Staff of DCTPCs are appointed partly by MCTPC, and partly by the provinces.  
Within the road sector, the DCTPC responsibilities include maintenance of national roads within 
each  province,  and  full  responsibility  for  construction,  improvement,  and  maintenance  of  the 
local road networks (provincial, district, and community roads). Each province has an average of 
75 DCTPC staff.  

3. 
As  of  June  2003,  DOR  has  90  permanent  staff;  72  are  professional  staff  and  18, 
technical  or  administrative.  But  another  41  staff  are  assigned  to  externally  financed  projects, 
bringing to total to 131.  

2. 

Road Network 

4. 
Transport in the Lao PDR is almost exclusively road-based. Roads, a key element of the 
basic  infrastructure,  carrying  about  70%  of  the  country’s  freight  and  90%  of  passenger  traffic. 
Thus,  roads  are  the  main  enabling  environment  to  support  regional  and  international  trade. 
Despite  many  advances  in  its  national  network,  the  Lao  PDR  continues  to  lag  behind  its 
neighbors  in  road  infrastructure  and  the  estimated  national  road  network  density  is  extremely 
low:  about  0.14  kilometers(km)/square  km.  The  Lao  PDR  has  a  road  network  of  about  32,600 
km;  national  roads  comprise  22%;  provincial  roads,  28%;  urban  roads,  4%;  and  district  or 
community roads, 46%. Only 14% of the total road network is paved; the other roads have gravel 
or  earth  surfaces.  Many  of  the  local  roads  are mere  tracks  and  are  impassable  during  the  wet 
season. Road contact between Vientiane and the provincial capitals is improving. But 4 of the 18 
provincial  capitals  remain  without  sealed,  all-weather  road  links.  Rehabilitation  of  some  roads 
included in the official national road network is still in the planning stage. The rehabilitation and 
improvement  of  the  roads  forming  the  core  arterial  network  have  been  completed,  or  are 
expected  to  be  completed  with  assistance  from  external  financing  agencies,  by  2005.  National 
Road (NR) 3, linking Thailand to China via the Lao PDR, is to be completed by 2007.

Maintenance 

10. 
The  Government  established  the  RMF  in  2001  as  a  means  of  providing  sustainable, 
domestic  funding  for  maintenance  of  the  national  road  network  and,  eventually,  all  roads.  The 
RMF1 is based on the principles of: (i) Funding. Road user fees are to contribute to the cost of 
maintaining the national road network, with 10% of RMF revenues initially going to local roads, 
and  the  RMF  progressively  contributing  to  the  full  cost  of  maintaining  all  roads;  (ii) 
Independence. An RMF board under MCTPC, which includes private sector representation, is 
to supervise, direct, and make recommendations on matters related to the overall management 
and  financing  of  road  maintenance;  (iii)  Revenues. Revenues  are  to  be  derived  from  user 
charges,  primarily  a  fuel  levy  on  gasoline  and  diesel  fuel,  heavy  vehicle  surcharges,  tolls,  and 
international  transit  charges.  The  fuel  levy  will  be  adjusted  annually,  collected  independently, 
and deposited directly to the RMF; (iv) Application. The priority is to be routine maintenance; (v) 
Administration. RMF is a separate account, operated and managed by the RMF board, and is 
not  part  of  the  Government's  general  revenue;  (vi)  Allocation. Allocation  for  network 
maintenance  is  to  be  based  on  needs,  functional  classification,  and  economic  considerations; 
and  (vii)  Auditing  and  reporting.  Accounts  are  subject  to  annual  audits,  by  independent 
auditors, in compliance with Government regulations.  

11. 
The  initial  charge  for  the  fuel  levy  is  $0.01/liter,  with  an  annual  increase  of  50%  from 
2002 to 2004, and 27% afterward. The annual heavy vehicle surcharges range from $25 for 2- to

Road Safety 

18. 
Fatalities  through  road  accidents  rose  by  245%  from  1991  to  1999.  Road  accidents 
themselves  increased  by  176%  during  the  same  period.  Road  fatalities  are  now  the  highest  in 
Southeast  Asia,  at  almost  20  persons  per  10,000  vehicles.  The  figure  is  growing  and  the 
potential  for  even  greater  accident  rates  is  high,  with  the  current  rate  of  increase  in  vehicles, 
growing population, and improved road networks. (DOT’s current target is to reduce the fatality 
rate  to  10  persons  per  10,000  vehicles.)  A  National  Road  Safety  Strategy  has  been  prepared 
that  is  built around  five  elements  (i)  education, (ii)  enforcement,  (iii)  technical  environment,  (iv) 
coordination, and (v) research and evaluation. The strategy’s key issues are (i) improved driving 
skills,  (ii)  use  of  crash  helmets  for  motorcycle  drivers,  (iii)  improved  night  visibility  for 
motorcyclists and cyclists, (iv) drunk driving, (v) speeding, (vi) traffic management, signing and 
delineation of roads, and (vii) use of seat belts. The Strategy, which is awaiting final approval of 
the  Prime  Minister,  envisages  implementation  through  a  national  road  safety  council  under 
MCTPC,  and  forging  of  a  road  safety  partnership  among  the  Traffic  Police  Department,  the 
Department  of  Transport,  and  the  Department  of  Education.  International  nongovernment 
organizations  (NGOs)  such  as  Handicap  International  support  efforts  to  create  a  network  to 
increase awareness of road safety issues and to address the trauma of road accidents. 

B. 

Government Objectives and Priorities for the Road Sector  

19. 
The  Government  has  given  high  priority  to  improvement  of  the  road  transport  system, 
mainly to facilitate (i) movement of agricultural products from surplus to deficit areas, (ii) flow of 
consumer goods and agricultural inputs to rural areas, (iii) marketing and export of cash crops 
and other produce, and (iv) participation in regional and international trade.Targets for physical 
infrastructure development include (i) completing the national road network, including road links 
with Cambodia, the People’s Republic of China, and Viet Nam, as well as road and bridge links 
with  Thailand;  (ii)  improving  the  provincial  road network;  (iii)  upgrading  transit  routes  to  central 
Viet  Nam  in  order  to  facilitate  the  Lao  PDR’s  international  trade  through  its  ports;  and  (iv) 
establishing a sustainable maintenance system to preserve the country’s transport infrastructure. 
Infrastructure  development,  particularly  roads,  is  being  coordinated  closely  with  regional 
cooperation initiatives being developed under the ADB Greater Mekong Subregion initiative, as 
the Lao PDR is located centrally among Cambodia, the Peoples’ Republic of China, Myanmar, 
Thailand, and Viet Nam. All-weather access roads are being provided to 16 of the Government's 
list of the 46 poorest districts through current or committed ADB projects including Xieng Khuang 
Road  Improvement,  Rural  Access  Roads,  and  Roads  for  Rural  Development.  MCTPC  is 
addressing the issue of  districts that do not have year-round road access, or no access at any 
time, through an ongoing plan as part of the National Poverty Eradication Programme.

FINANCIAL PERFORMANCE AND PROJECTIONS OF ROAD MAINTENANCE FUND 

1. 
The Road Maintenance Fund (RMF) was established in 2001 with technical and financial 
support  from  the  World  Bank  and  the  Nordic  Development  Fund  (NDF)  under  Phase  1  of  the 
World Bank’s Road Maintenance Project (RMP-1). RMP-1 is coordinated with technical support 
to  the  Ministry  of  Communications,  Transport,  Post,  and  Construction  (MTCPT)  from  the 
Swedish International Development Agency (Sida) under the second Lao-Swedish Road Sector 
Project  (LSRSP-2).  ADB  had  previously  allocated  $2  million  to  the  funding  of  maintenance 
through RMF under Loan 1795-LAO.

2. 
A  joint  World  Bank  and  Sida  mid-term  review  mission  visited  Laos  to  review  RMP-1  in 
October  2003.  The  mission  concluded  that  the  Project—and  thus,  the  RMF—was  developing 
satisfactorily.  The  Project  was  meeting  its  development  objectives,  and  most  key  performance 
indicators  (KPIs)  had  been  met  for  this  stage.  The  review  mission  noted  that  three  trigger  KPI 
targets  had  been  met,  so  appraisal for  phase  2  of  the  RMP  could  begin.  Most  remaining  KPIs 
had met their targets, and the others were expected to meet targets, but with some delay. KPIs 
that had already been met included: lengths of national and local roads subject to periodic and 
routine maintenance; percentages of vehicles overloaded on national roads; review of the third 
maintenance  program  (MP-3)  by  the  Road  Fund  Advisory  Board  (RMFAB);  publication  of 
RMFAB accounts and audit; production of performance monitoring reports; and establishment of 
village maintenance committees. KPIs that had been partially met include a 50% yearly increase 
in fuel levy  (one increase has been authorized, but a second is now overdue); prioritization of 
the road maintenance program, using the road management system that has been established, 
and is now being tested through the RMP; operation of the monitoring and evaluation system for 
local roads (whose recent use is now being reviewed); and preparation of a national strategy for 
development of domestic contracting and consulting.  

3. 
RMF was set up as a second-generation road fund that will collect road user charges to 
finance  routine  and  periodic  road  maintenance.  Sources  of  income  are  road  tolls  on  selected

vehicles, international transit fees for trucks, and a fuel levy. The road tolls, the overloading fines 
and the fuel levy became effective in 2002. The fuel levy will be the main source of income. It

The benefit and cost analysis of the proposed Roads for Rural Development Project was 
prepared using on the road economic decision (RED)1 model, which was adjusted for conditions

comparing the “with” and the “without” project cases. The analysis is based on the direct benefits 
arising  from  savings  in  transport  and  road  maintenance  costs  due  to  the  Project.  The  Project 
was evaluated through to 2027, allowing a 3-year construction period starting in 2005, followed 
by a benefit period of 20 years. The analysis incorporates future routine, recurrent, and periodic 
maintenance costs of the project roads.

3.

motorable project roads. Each traffic count was carried out for 12 hours on 3 consecutive days in 
November  2002.  Normal  traffic  growth  was  estimated  using  the  growth  rates  that  had  been 
adopted  in  an  earlier  study  of  the  project  roads,  with  no  differentiation  among  vehicle  types  or 
regions of the country. The rates used were 10% per year for the first half of the 20-year benefit 
period, and 8% per year afterward. These values are commensurate with recently experienced 
growth in road traffic and in vehicle registrations in the Lao PDR, and with the projected growth 
of  population  and  gross  domestic  product.  Divertible  traffic  was  identified  in  two  places:  (i)  on 
road  section  1.01  (Sayabury–Ban  Natak);  and  (ii)  on  road  section  6.02  (Houayla–Ban  Vang).

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in the Lao PDR:
The poor in the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (the Lao PDR) are heavily burdened by lack of access to goods and 
labor markets and social services. Access deprivation results in high transportation costs that reduce the mobility of 
people and goods produced by the poor. Access deprivation also results in reduced or lack of access to consumer 
goods, social services, information, and market and livelihood opportunities for labor, with consequent implications for 
income and socioeconomic welfare. Poor households in areas with limited access are often unable to overcome the 
cost barriers of mobility. This results in high levels of subsistence, with high vulnerability to external shocks and food 
shortages.

Poor rural access to the rest of the economy implies that overall economic growth has limited impact on the rural poor. 
The result is increased inequalities between rural and urban areas. The Lao PDR achieved remarkable reductions in 
poverty during the 1990s, much of it resulting from economic growth. But remote and access-deprived provinces 
experienced significant less poverty reduction, and poverty incidence even increased in some areas. For instance, 
Borikhamxay Province, which is part of the Project, experienced a 15% increase of poverty, while poverty in the 
economy as a whole declined by more than 6%.          

The road sector plays a key role in improving accessibility in a land-locked economy such as the Lao PDR. Improved 
accessibility implies that mobility of people, goods, and services increase, and will affect prices. But the extent of 
increase in mobility will largely depend on policies of transport services, including outreach and tariffs, and the demand 
and affordability of such services.   

While road accessibility will inevitably improve access to social services, including health and education, by shortening 
the time and cost of traveling, the provision of services will also become more cost-effective with improved accessibility. 
Therefore, while impacts of improved accessibility will take place, the extent of impacts will depend on government 
policies and the ability of the Government to provide these services. Data also suggest that all-weather village 
accessibility determines overall welfare and poverty at the village level. On the national level, per capita expenditures 
were found to be 46% higher for villages with all-weather access vs those with no access, and 21% higher than in 
villages that have only dry season access.    

Road access is a key underlying condition for poverty reduction in the Lao PDR, both in terms of ability and cost 
effectiveness of targeting services to the poor, and in poverty reduction benefits that result from economic growth. Most 
of the poor live in rural areas with limited access. Improved road access will remove cost barriers in the provision of 
social services and enhance the ability of the poor to benefit from overall economic growth. Thus, the impacts of 
improved accessibility on poverty reduction can be both direct and indirect, with multisectoral implications, especially 
with respect to education and health.   

Increased road access also integrates the project areas into the larger context of the economy. Integration promotes 
economic growth for the overall economy by allowing those areas to contribute to the economy, and vice versa. 
Integration also enables the population to better benefit from economic growth.

Poverty and Development Impact 

Improving access will reduce vulnerability to food shortages by facilitating the flow of goods from surplus to deficit 
areas. Road access is critically important for villages and districts to cope with rice deficits. Table A12.3 shows the 
potential for reducing rice deficits along three project roads that would link rice-deficit areas with surplus areas. Poor 
road access is closely linked with rice deficits, higher poverty levels, and higher food prices for consumers, especially 
for the poor. At the same time, poor producers receive lower prices for their produce in areas with poor access. This 
relative price distortion is due to high transactions costs for areas in relative isolation. High transaction costs are 
determined by transportation costs and monopoly traders. Because the poor market through traders, they are especially 
affected by the poor road access. Thus, the subprojects would be expected to have significant impact on the ability of 
poor villages to cope with rice and food shortages, and reduce the cost of coping strategies.     

With improved roads, transportation costs will be reduced. Price data for poor and good roads suggest that poor 
consumers will benefit through lower consumer prices and poor producers will benefit through higher producer prices. 
But the extent to which the poor will benefit will depend on the availability and competition among transport providers 
and traders. Other factors that may influence the relative price change may include education and ethnicity, because 
these factors may influence the bargaining powers of the end consumer and producers. With increased competition 
among traders, however, the influence of cultural factors on bargaining power tends to decrease.  

Poor road access is strongly correlated with lower education levels and low access to health facilities and services. All-
weather access means that the village population would be able to travel to district centers for health care year-round. 
Furthermore, health care and education services tend to expand and improve as villages become accessible.  This 
would be expected to improve welfare and reduce treatment costs, especially for the poor since they are more 
vulnerable to diseases and to the cost of transportation to medical facilities.

Road Safety and Poverty

Improved roads are often a mixed blessing for the poor. Although road access is critically important for access to health
care, the increased traffic volume resulting from road improvement also means increased need for health care—
because of injuries from traffic accidents. These adverse impacts tend to disproportionately impact on the poor. The
poor are affected directly, as the most vulnerable vehicle and road users, and indirectly, in terms of health service 
needs that traffic injuries impose, but that cannot be met, and in terms of the impact on gross domestic product (GDP). 
The impact of a traffic injury on a member of a poor household can be devastating in terms of health costs and loss of 
income and livelihood activities. Within poor families, the main providers and children going to school often face a 
higher probability of traffic injury than other family members, because they use roads more. Poor traffic safety
measures protecting the poor means lost opportunities for poverty reduction. Little has been done to examine the 
impact of road safety issues on poverty, so a study will be conducted, as part of capacity building, to specifically
address the vulnerability of the poor to traffic accidents, and to examine the social and economic costs of poor traffic 
safety to the poor. The project also includes specific measures to address road safety issues along the project roads.

Strategy to Address Issues

A resettlement plan has been prepared for the Pakxane-Thasi,
Sayabury-Hongsa, and Xaisetha-Sanxai roads. A resettlement 
framework has been prepared for the Pakton-Ban Vang and
Hongsa-Thaxoan roads.

Affordability will increase because improved access will enhance
cash income and employment opportunities. Information suggests
that availability of transport services and traders will increase as a 
result of road improvement, and that tariffs will be reduced by as 
much as 67%. But the extent of tariff reductions for transport
services will depend on competition among transport service
operators. Tariffs will be closely monitored as part of the project
performance monitoring system.
Enhanced access is expected to induce labor migration. The
impact will be mainly positive for households.

ADB’s Policy on Indigenous People was initiated because 75% of 
the populations along the Xaisetha-Sanxai and Sayabury-Hongsa
roads belong to ethnic minorities who may be vulnerable to
changes that the road improvements cause. Because the 
communities are made up of both ethnic minority and majority
peoples, a community development plan was prepared to meet
the requirements of an ethnic minority development plan for the
two roads. The small number of ethnic minorities along the 
Pakxane-Thasi road will not be disproportionately vulnerable
because of their ethnicity and cultures, and therefore, do not
trigger the ADB’s Indigenous Peoples Policy. A resettlement and 
community development framework has been prepared for the 
Pakton-Ban Vang and Hongsa-Thaxoan roads.
Road Safety: A study of impacts of road safety on the poor, plus a 
road safety program, including village awareness and training
programs, will be implemented. Fencing is included in the
resettlement plan.

HIV/AIDS and SDT: An HIV/AIDS and STD awareness and
prevention program is needed to mitigate risks from the influx of
construction workers and increased mobility as a result of road 
improvements. Issues identified and strategies are being
prepared. Detailed designs are to be done in conjunction with
implementation.

Trafficking of Women and Children: A program for awareness
and prevention of trafficking, and promotion of safe migration, is 
planned to prevent negative outcomes from increased mobility
from areas with improved roads.

Land Tenure: Households along the project roads need land titles 
in the names of both husband and wife for tenure security, and
awareness of their rights. Issues identified and strategies to 
address them are being prepared. Detailed designs will be 
initiated in conjunction with implementation.

ADB = Asian Development Bank, HIV/AIDS = human immunodeficiency virus/acquired immunodeficiency syndrome,
STD = Sexually Transmitted Diseases.
